msContents.summary: 45-47 are receipts from the payment of taxes for the annona militaris by Theodoros, son of Obodianos to the same persons. 45 and 46 were rolled together, and 47 was discovered within 20 cm of them. Payments are evidently not made to ofﬁcials, but rather to previous owners of the plots mentioned in each text. According to the general practice in Petra, although land had changed ownership, the tax registers were for some reason not updated for several years and the previous owner remained responsible for the tax payments.The two persons who receive Theodoros’ payments in 47 and sign the receipt are called Patrikios, son of Ailianos, and Ailianos, son of Monaxios.

msItemStruct.note: Written transversa charta. Three margins are extant: top margin at least 1 cm, left margin at least 1 cm and bottom margin 1 c. The right side has been completely lost. Three hands are easily distinguished. The ﬁrst is a ﬂuent and practiced hand that has written the receipt. The second and third hands are those of Flavius Patrikios, son of Ailianos, and Flavius Ailianos, son of Monaxios, with all the names preserved. In particular, the hand of Ailianos betrays an aura of elegance.

div.ab: [(1. H.) [†] The most God-pleasing [Theodoros, son of Obodianos,] has given [on account of his taxes, from the] now passed [ﬁrst indiction until the] present sixth [and including it, for six years,] for .. . landed property that devolved [on him . . .] the place Khafa . . . the place Mal . . . . . one twentieth . . . for the place called Mal Sar . . . one thirtieth, one seventieth, [making together?. . . ] one ninetieth, all the [exacted and extra (taxes) in] farm products and in oinokreon [and in ? products according to] the imperial delegatio. Written in the month . . . of the year . . . in the sixth indiction]. (2. H.) [†] I, Flavius Patrikios, son of Ailianos, [ . . . have received (jointly?)] one half [part] of the above-written [taxes . . . ] one ninetieth, from the ﬁrst[. . . to the present] sixth indiction and [including it, six years, . . . ] having signed accordingly [with my own hand. †] (3. H.) [†] I Flavius Ailianos, son of Monaxios, [ . . . have received jointly] one half part of the above-written [taxes, from the ﬁrst to the] sixth in diction and including it, [six] years,[having signed accordingly] with my own hand. †
